title: Asos walks down the aisle towards handsome profits
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Tue, Jul 7, 2015, 23:56 BST - UK Markets closed Asos walks down the aisle towards handsome profits By Ashley Armstrong | Telegraph – 5 hours ago 3,820.20 -30.80 
Online fashion retailer upgrades revenue forecasts after a boost in UK sales from bridesmaid dresses and festival wear 
Bridesmaid dresses and festival outfits helped boost orders at Asos (LSE: ASC.L - news ) , prompting the online fashion retailer to upgrade its annual sales forecast to the top end of City expectations. 
The company reported a 20pc lift in total retail sales to £386m in the four months to the end of June, after a robust performance from its US and European businesses. 
The UK arm performed strongly, too, with sales up 27 per cent to £158m. 
Nick Robertson, Asos' chief executive, said that sales had also been propelled by extending the cut-off time for next-day delivery to midnight. “We have seen an uplift in traffic to the site in the later hours of the evening”, he said. 
Asos has moved to take advantage of "wedding season" with the introduction of bridesmaids outfits 
Asos has also spent the past 18 months introducing so-called “zonal pricing”, which allows it to alter the cost of goods in different regions so that prices are competitive and in line with the local market, rather than based on UK prices. It also gives Asos the ability to adjust prices as local currencies fluctuate in value. 
The move has drastically improved international sales, which grew 16pc in the period to £227.6m. 
However, there were pockets of weak trading and in some international markets, growth appeared to have stalled. In Russia, Asos has been forced to drop prices by as much as 40pc to offset the fall in the value of the rubel currency. 
Mr Robertson said that international sales would continue to be “challenging” as a result of Russian troubles, but that it would be offset by strong performances in France and Germany. 
The Asos chief said that there were no plans to quit Russia as they had “no physical presence to pull out of, we operate a website and we ship goods there". 
Nick Robertson (centre) 
Asos has recently started stocking items by rival online retailers Boohoo.com and Missguided, although it insists that it acts as a platform for 850 different brands. Mr Robertson said that sales continued to be split evenly between Asos own-label products and other brands. 
Georgina Johanan at JPMorgan (LSE: JPIU.L - news ) called Asos “more than just a clothing retailer”. 
“It offers a unique combination of over 800 third-party brands, an own-label product that has been developed into a dynamic brand in its own right, and rich-media content designed to promote its status as a fashion destination for its target audience. 
"Combined with an attractive delivery proposition, this has driven rapid sales growth, enabling Asos to further invest in customer service and marketing and to secure incremental brands and drive further traffic.” 
However, some City analysts have raised questions over the high levels of sales returns at Asos. 
Mr Robertson said that the average returns rate had inched higher to around 37pc of total sales, from 35pc the year before. But he said this was driven by strong sales in Germany, where the typical rate of returns averages around 65pc of all sales. 
He also dismissed concerns over the issue, saying it was evidence of consumers "becoming more familiar with the ease with which they can buy and return goods to Asos", stressing the comany was still selling clothes at a profit.
